awd_titl_txt: BCSER: Increasing Interest in Ecological and Environmental Sciences to Broaden Participation of African Americans in STEM
awd_abstract_narration:
This project explores approaches to increase the participation of African Americans in environmental and ecological sciences.  The project aims to achieve this goal by designing and testing an intervention designed to improve the recruitment of African Americans into environmental and ecological sciences programs and careers. The project will support a combination of exploratory research and professional development activities.  The professional development plan centers on helping the investigator acquire expertise in qualitative research methods and in the engagement of minority populations in a formal research setting. Professional development activities will include site visits to study locations, mentoring from coaches and advisors, and attendance at relevant conferences.  This project aims to position the investigator to conduct longer term research towards broadening participation in ecological and environmental sciences.

The research project is grounded in identity-based motivation theory and cultural mismatch theory of inequality, and uses social science constructs to collect and analyze the research data.  The project has three research questions: (1) Do perceived historical and contemporary constraints influence students' pursuit of ecological and environmentally related STEM disciplines? (2) Does the intervention induce an alignment of African American identity and value system towards greater interest and motivation in ecological and environmentally related STEM disciplines? and (3) Does the intervention induce a shift in perceptions concerning the importance of ecological integrity and biodiversity?  The intervention will engage undergraduate students in a summer research and enrichment experience that incorporates constructs to increase interest and motivation to pursue ecological and environmental disciplines. Pilot data will be collected on the effectiveness of the experience and analyzed using qualitative methods.  The research will provide insights about the influence of contextualized interventions in addressing STEM education research topics.

The project is supported through the EHR Core Research: Building Capacity in STEM Education Research (ECR: BCSER) competition that is designed to build individuals' capacity to carry out high quality fundamental STEM education research in STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM fields, and STEM workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project provided an opportunity to conduct an exploratory science education research project while building capacity for STEM education research. Spatially, this work focused on a regional placed-based scope that spans across the Southeastern United States (SE US) exploring aspects of identity-based motivation theory and cultural mismatch theory of inequality. Intervention constructs investigated in this project, implemented predominately during summer immersion programs, were aimed at testing approaches to broaden participation among African Americans (AAs) in sustainability, environmental sciences, and ecology, as well as to improve stakeholder engagement in the environmental sector. A total of four summer programs were conducted, one virtual and three face to face engagements, hosting undergraduate students from universities spanning the SE US and beyond. During face to face programming, students participated in four-week immersions within a watershed paradigm, and included travel and water quality sampling across Mountain, Piedmont, and Coastal Plain physiographic provinces. Summer programming was based out of Johnson C. Smith University’s (JCSU) Center for Renewable Energy and Sustainability (CRES), situated in the Piedmont, where students were able to learn about stakeholder engagement and environmental agency while participating in sustainable urban agricultural practices at the CRES Sustainability Village urban farm outfitted with organic soil based raised beds and a suite of hydroponic and aquaponic grow systems. In the mountains, the program operated out of the Highlands Biological Station in western North Carolina, where aspects of SE US biodiversity were explored firsthand, along with the historical importance of land and natural resources for the indigenous Cherokee Nation. During coastal excursions, the program operated out of the Baruch Marine Field Lab which is a NOAA National Estuarine Research Reserve (NERR) site located in the South Carolina Lowcountry. While on the coast, students engaged with members of the Gullah Geechee people learning intersections of land and culture. Additional student engagement took place across the academic calendar, predominately with JCSU natural science majors.

Our student engagement was intentionally framed within the ecosystem services framework and seeked to awaken social and environmental justice agency. Following introductory prompts, students participated in cogenerative discussions to reflect on AA values and identity as a means to motivate environmental engagement. Cultural connections and socio-environment interrelations were underscored while the conservation of biodiversity is highlighted as a requisite for the continued delivery of ecosystem services. The intervention strategy considered persistent poverty among predominantly rural AA populations in the SE US in the context of African descendant people’s original settlement in this region. Quantitative survey data results indicated that both historical (i.e. segregation) and modern social biases (i.e. systemic biases, family perceptions of success) discourage and continue to discourage AA engagement in environmentally related STEM disciplines (p<0.05). An analysis Pre and Post intervention survey data indicated that the intervention also increased student’s perceptions on the importance of biodiversity (p<0.05). Finally, student’s post intervention survey results indicated strong agreement that the ecosystem services framework: resonates positively with the historical identity and culture of AA’s, and is a meaningful lobbying platform when advocating for capital investment as a “reparations proxy” for predominately AA communities that remain in persistent poverty.

Professional development and capacity building goals were met through direct and continual advisement from Dr. Brenda Brand who is a STEM education researcher and Professor in Virginia Tech’s School of Education. Dr. Brand’s mentorship provided an opportunity for the P.I. to combine newly gained proficiencies in STEM education research with his environmental research skills and experiences to ultimately broaden participation in the ecological and environmental sciences. This experience also positively contributed to the establishment of professional networking relationships that will foster longer term research engagement towards broadening minority participation in ecological and environmental sciences.

Contextualizing this NSF research experience with the P.I.’s position as Director of CRES and Assistant Professor of Ecology, this project has become a springboard for establishing a comprehensive environmental program at JCSU. Leadership at both Highlands Biological Station and the Baruch Marine Field Lab, along with Gullah Geechee partners, are all interested to identify opportunities to collaborate on future projects. As an extension of this NSF project, the P.I. has secured additional funding to work with new and existing partners in establishing a pipeline to simultaneously connect K-12 students to JCSU while providing research and workforce development opportunities for undergraduate students. All parties are eager to work towards establishing JCSU’s CRES as a hub for education research aimed at broadening participation among AAs in the environmental sector.
